channel.title: Sleep documentation
channel.description:
Hello everyone, and welcome to my [i]sleep documentation[/i] thread. I have been very interested in the research of sleeping patterns, and school has started back, so I figured I would do various tests to minimize the time I sleep, but maximize the efficiency of the sleep. According to various sources, the refreshment of the sleep is not determined by the length of the sleep, but the timing of when you wake up during your sleep cycles, which should always be [i]between[/i] your sleeping cycles, in which a human should go through 5-6 cycles which last 90 minutes each. These are not facts, so please do not flame about them being true or not, but please acknowledge that these have been determined through research, which is completely biased depending on the person.
Anyways, now to move onto the actual documentation. I have always had issues with sleeping, almost never getting a good night's rest, because I do one of the following:
[ul][li]Sleep [i]too much[/i][/li] [li]Sleep [i]too little[/i][/li][/ul] Below, I will have a code block dedicated to the documentation of each night of sleep I get. The format will be the same as follows; [i]date[/i]: [i]sleep start[/i] - [i]sleep end[/i] | [i]sleep cycles[/i] - [i]SUCCESS/FAILURE[/i]: [code] 8/18/2013: 1:30AM - 6:00AM | 3 - SUCCESS 8/19/2013: 1:30AM - 6:00AM | 3 [/code]
I am aware that there are various things that effect sleep, and I will take those into consideration once I have tested each sleeping cycle, so I can see which will be a reasonable pattern to start off with. Feel free to post your thoughts/results if you are interested in this certain topic.
[b]Information to undergo your own research:[/b]
[ul][li]Sleep cycles usually last around 90 minutes[/li] [li]The average amount of sleep cycles required to have the 'best' sleep is generally 5-6[/li] [li]The average amount of time it takes to fall asleep is 14 minutes.[/li] [li]Timing greatly affects the efficiency of your sleep pattern. [/li][/ul]
For example: If you are scheduled to go to sleep at 1:30, make sure you are in the bed and attempt to sleep as soon as the clock strikes 1:16, which will allow the 14 minutes for you to fall asleep, which will help prevent you from waking in the middle of a sleep cycle.

item.title: Sleep documentation
item.dc:creator: @the_elve_age the elve age
item.description:
@the_elve_age wrote:

3 hours of sleep a night? Unless you’re a full grown man, you need at least 8 hours of sleep for you to be healthy. I’ll keep following this

Read full topic

item.title: Sleep documentation
item.dc:creator: @silabsoft RuneAgent
item.description:
@silabsoft wrote:

if you truly want to help your sleep situation really need to stay away from the caffeine your body does get used to it even if you don’t feel cravings for it

Read full topic

item.description:
@Yz85Racer wrote:

I’ve used Sleep Cycle, an app on my phone, for the past 2 years. works just as well

Read full topic

item.title: Sleep documentation
item.dc:creator: @Tutorial Tutorial
item.description:
@Tutorial wrote:

Surprisingly, I slept really good last night and woke up feeling refreshed. I started my day with a coffee and cereal, and then headed off to school. I saw no signs of performance loss, and I was able to center my focus on each and every class. After school, I worked out and then headed off to work. I just got back from work, and I have some studying to do for some tests, so I will actually stay up till 1:30 again and wake up at 6:00, and hopefully this will help me determine if this pattern is right for me. Eventually, I will try to mix it up every night until I find the best results.

Jc22493:

You can’t do this accurately without more advanced technology. You may want to sleep at 10:30 PM, but fall asleep at 11:04 PM, etc.

I don’t see how this would prove to be a huge impact on the tests.

For example: If you are scheduled to go to sleep at 1:30, make sure you are in the bed and attempt to sleep as soon as the clock strikes 1:16, which will allow the 14 minutes for you to fall asleep, which will help prevent you from waking in the middle of a sleep cycle.
I provided this example to show how I will be conducting these tests. It shouldn't take me any longer than 20 minutes to fall asleep, and that is pretty far fetched.

But yes, technology would most likely provide the best results.

Read full topic

item.title: Sleep documentation
item.dc:creator: @amy_webb1 amy_webb
item.description:
@amy_webb1 wrote:

Despite lack of technology and precise patterns, i’m interested in seeing how this turns out. It will be fairly informative to see the result of this, and how effectively the sleep patterns being planned out will work. Good luck.

Read full topic

it is intended to revolve around the discussion of sleeping patterns based upon the documentation of different results. if you aren’t interested, please do not post on this thread.

item.description:
@Tutorial wrote:

Hello everyone, and welcome to my sleep documentation thread. I have been very interested in the research of sleeping patterns, and school has started back, so I figured I would do various tests to minimize the time I sleep, but maximize the efficiency of the sleep. According to various sources, the refreshment of the sleep is not determined by the length of the sleep, but the timing of when you wake up during your sleep cycles, which should always be between your sleeping cycles, in which a human should go through 5-6 cycles which last 90 minutes each. [li]Sleep too little[/li][/ul]

8/18/2013: 1:30AM - 6:00AM | 3 - SUCCESS
8/19/2013: 1:30AM - 6:00AM | 3

[li]The average amount of time it takes to fall asleep is 14 minutes.[/li]

For example: If you are scheduled to go to sleep at 1:30, make sure you are in the bed and attempt to sleep as soon as the clock strikes 1:16, which will allow the 14 minutes for you to fall asleep, which will help prevent you from waking in the middle of a sleep cycle.
